docs.lead_paragraph: They can be found everywhere, from the warehouse to the moving van to the gym. Some four million of them were bought in 1995 alone. But do they do any good? They are back belts, the wide swaths of material that many people cinch around their waists when they lift heavy materials. Many companies even require employees to wear them.

headline.main: Doubts Cast on Merits of Back Belts

docs.abstract: Study of workers who do heavy lifting casts doubt on benefits of weight-lifting belts in preventing back injuries; National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health study is published in Journal of the American Medical Assn; drawing (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A third of American doctors do not have a regular doctor, a new study finds, a ratio much higher than for the overall population. Writing in The Archives of Internal Medicine, Yale researchers said they were surprised by the finding. Failing to have a regular doctor, the researchers said, led some to neglect preventive care.

headline.main: Doctors Who Could Use a Doctor

docs.abstract: Yale researchers find that one third of American doctors do not themselves have a regular doctor, ratio much higher than for overall population; research is published in Archives of Internal Medicine (S)
